column2: My2Livers, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I used Prograf for 5 yrs post-liver-xplant, and became increasingly paranoid, confused and delusional during that time. My docs said "You're bi-polar" & put me in the mental hospital. I'm not bi-polar, but I sure appeared to be. After doing my own research, I discovered that brain damage, paranoia, hallucinations, mania and even hair loss are COMMON side effects. I showed my doc my print-out w/ my symptoms hi-lighted, and he weaned me off prograf. Now I'm only on cellcept. That was 3 years ago, and I'm no longer crazy. But I have psoriasis, which just spread to my face, and just discovered that prograf topical is used for psoriasis! hmmm.. lose my hair and my mind or walk around w/ red blotches all over my face? I'm alive anyway, and I'm glad for all of U who are similarly blessed. Has anyone tried this stuff for psoriasis? Maybe topical won't affect my psyche! thx for any input. Peace.

Since starting Program I have had Lympoma with in 2 years after starting Prograf. With in the last 12 months I have gotten to were it is effecting my sleep now. As for how it works on my rejection it is great but so was the others.

column2: 3PRZMOR, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I GET A LOT OF HEADACHES, EAR N TEETH PAIN, MY EYES, N LOSING MEMORY N HEARING, VERY SLOW ALMOST UNNOTICEABLE. MY WHITE OR RED CELLS LOW.

column2: brandy, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Taking 5,1mg caps daily, split into two doses for 5 years now. Only annoyance is hand tremors but recently found out about tegretol for tremors. Tegretol has been effective in reducing tremors greatly. WARNING>you do have to be diligent about avoiding people with contagious diseases. I recently contracted RSV which landed me on life support due to pneumonia. Am back to "normal" now thankfully.

column1: Management of Body's Rejection to a Transplanted Kidney
column2: legitlbiochemist, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
dizneeboi, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Liver transplant 9 yrs ago, congenital hepatic fibrosis. 3mg twice a day, high blood pressure and hand tremors. I drop things all the time. Lucky no rejection or major side effects. Cost of the drug gets to be a bit much sometimes, scared to switch to generics. Life is a gift

column2: bev5419, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I had a liver transplant on 12/13/2001 at Jackson Memorial Hospital.I receive my liver from my daughter which is such a blessing to get a second chance in life. My transplant was due to Cryptogenic Liver Cirrhosis. My life changed dramatically but I have no complaints because I am ALIVE. I have been on prograf since my transplant. I had a rejection in 2004 when my enzymes went up and a bx was done. Since the rejection I have been taking 2mg in the am and 1 mg in the pm along with 8mg medrol twice a week. Since May of this year, my  liver enzymes elevated and my doses were increased to 2mg in am and 2mg in pm. My Drs also increase the medrol to 12 mg.Thank God so far my enymes level went down to normal and I hope they stay normal. I just did my labs on 7/5 hopefully the results are normal. I am hoping my Drs will be dcreasing the meds again. SIDE EFFECTS High BP, anxious,ect but the benefits to me is greater than the risk of side effects. But its  been a life change since my transplant. No complaints at all because I am so very happy to be alive now. Thank God for my daughter and the medications. God bless everyone and thankful for all.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I am on 10mg per day and I have noticed more forgetfullness than before my transplant.  I do see a nuerologist and have been given numerous tests and the only exxplanation he can give me is that it comes froms my anti rejection meds.

column2: mexgyver, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: headaches, tremors, nausea, sluggish.

column2: Crossroads miracle, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I recieved a liver transplant on 07/30/06, I walked out of the Methodist in Memphis 3 days later. I'm known as the "One and only".  It took about 6 months to get at my current med. levels.  I take .1mg in the morning and .05 at night.  I have not had any side effects. Although it wasnt recommended to use the generics and so far I havnt.  Good luck to all reading this because if you need this drug then your life is changing for the better!!!

column2: 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more
column9: Transplated in Sept 1998. Have taken 3mg twice a day since then. Also taking azathiaprine and prednisone. No rejection episodes. No side effects from the prograf. Have worked full-time and travelled the world the entire time.

column2: maryann, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Hi had my liver transplant 4 years ago  i am on 1mg in morning and a half mg. at night i think that i am a poster child for prograf.When they put me on a half it was generic got a bad rash put me back on regulas prograf doing great no other pills. THEY are starting to see numbers with kidney level. Is there anyone outthere that is taking that amount?

column2: jojo, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Had a kidney transplant @ UCSF in 12/2009.  Only side effect for me has been hair loss / change.  Dr. says this tends to happen with Prograf.  Totally changed the structure of my hair & it is now very thin.  Also came in curlier.  But otherwise, no side effects.

column2: britlite3, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Had a kidney transplant 6 years ago and no problems until a few months ago. Vision would go from being great and seconds later blurred - sometimes back to normal, could not trim shrubs without having to stop 5 mins. later from shaking, can't sleep without the help of 1/2 to 1 tab of Valium before bedtime - that does the trick- Then, there is weight gain - maybe from the junk food :) But I consider myself very lucky - I started out taking 1.5 mg 2x daily - now it's been reduced to 1 mg. 2x daily. This drug is great - it's given me a chance to see my girls grow up. Much better than being on chemo and dialysis any day. I had RPG with P-ANKA - so I'll take the Prograf anytime. Thanks to this great drug company for giving us another chance. We are the lucky ones - never forget that. Stay positive :) you could be back where you were before your transplant. God is good :)Life is good!!!

column2: rocky24, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Transplant 6/03. Nightsweats only thing. Hep C has just started to affect my new liver. take 1mg 2x daily. Nothing else. Did have a problem with diabetes but that is now controlled when weaneded off prednisone and smaller amts of prograf.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been on and off this drug for 13+ years.  Before transplant  I was on 30+ mg but now only 5mg daily.  When I was on the higher dose I gained 45 pounds, grew hair where I didn't want it and lost it where I wanted to keep it and my cheeks were very puffy.  Now almost 5 years post transplant everything is normal except for osteoporosis but I am alive so I am very thankful!!

column2: fiberwiz, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: My Kidney transplant was in Jan. 2010 at The Emory Transplant Center. I am very happy with this drug and Cellcept, which I also take. My current dose is 6mg AM and 5mg PM. The only side effects I have noticed are shaky hands, night sweats and loss of short term memory.

column2: mike623952, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: om or about aug 2010 the prograf went very low in 2 out of 5 test withen 2 week period it was at level of <3 or less i doubled the intake as soon as i found out it went to normal ie avg of 10 so i checked the ones i had i found 2 of 6 caps i ckeked were empty itold my provider my drs and and my hospital they all saw the test  and they all aggre that i did right, and becouse oif that my kenndy wenet from 1.46 to 1.72now all the drs are taking a closer look ty ps 1 dr said i had 0 level of prograf in my systeam my drs are from UCLA  and CEAARS/ SINAI

column2: likkitt222221111, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: taken from 1999 all side effect but no rejection

column2: chris, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I had a kidney transplant on 4/19/2009.  I take 2mg 2x a day.  I have some side effects such as GI distress, tremors (once in while), nervous and I am not sure, but I recently started having pain in my neck and jaw on the right side of my body only.  I also seem to have some swelling in my hip and lower back on the same side of my body.  Overall, it does prevent rejection.  I did have a lot of infections in beginning about 4 months after my transplant.

column2: maureensainato1, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
wsnpc126, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Like others I experienced the hair loss side effect. I have a great hair stylist - they work with the American Cancer Society Look good feel better program. They recommended I use the scalp/hair treatment chemo patients use - Nioxin. It is wonderful! About 1 month after treatmend - new hair started growing in - I had long hair, had it cut short and kept it that way until the new hair was long enough, you couldn't tell the difference. Now it's growing back out and looks great.Good luck I hope it works for anyone going through this. Being a recipient is great but being female without hair, it's a vanity thing! It gave me glimpse into the life of a cancer patient. Much respect

column2: madfish121, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I suppose this is the best anti-rejection med on the market right now but I still don't think it is very good. I have had chronic vomiting from the very start as well as lower GI problems and hand tremors. I am also losing my hair. I had an episode of rejection while on this medication even though my prograf blood level was optimal. It keeps my kidney alive though and for that I am grateful.

column2: donatealife, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I had liver transplant 3/09 due to hep c resulting in liver disease. My doctors believe it was result of multiple blood transfusions I received in mid 70's during birth of kids. I feel very blessed to have received my liver from one of my daughters and have been given a second chance @ life. I was equally as blessed to find myself in the incredible hands of doctors surgeons, coordinators,and nurses at Mt Sinai Hospital. They are a unique group of people that did not just treat our medical needs but also our souls. Their care and kindness shown to my entire family is something we will always carry in our hearts. I currently take 4mg.of prograf (2x) daily.I was initally takng .5mg (2x) daily. It has gradually increased to the current dosage, which has remained at this level since 12/09. I have difficulty sleeping, find myself short tempered and a bit emotional and anxious at times. Many foods don't agree with my stomach, so I avoid them. I have begun with muscle cramps the past few months. I'm not sure if this is related to the prograf or cellcept 500 mg(2x) daily. My next app't is in Sept. Seems like I am taking a high dose of prograf in comparison to other postings I have read. regardless of the side effects of meds before my transplant I was existing through my day, I am now living in my day!!

column2: Mary, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: By the seventh day of taking prograf,I began noticing a dimming/darkening of my vision.  By the 2nd month I was completely blind in one eye and had lost about 3/4 of vision in the other. Opthamologists & neurologist say the optic nerves have been severely damaged; eyes had been checked less than 2 months before transplants.  Eye that still has vision stopped losing vision after discontinuing prograf.We have found some case studies listing this as a rare side effect of Prograf, but my transplant team were not even aware of it. It should be better publicized.   My life has changed dramatically because damage to the optic nerves is irrevocable. And, it's the full black out type of blindness in one eye and a small tunnel remaining for the other.Prograf seems to have worked fine as an anti-rejection med, but this rare side effect exacted too high of a price.

column2: joyce, 65-74 Female  (Patient)
column9: the only side effect that has been problematic is migraine headache. these render me helpless with many trips to the emergency room by ambulance.

column2: Rosie, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I had a liver transplant 12 years ago and this drug was introduced about 8 years ago . I have been taking it with no problems. I did start getting foot cramps and I do have disk degeneration. I guess hearing some of the problems other people are having I consider myself pretty lucky!

column2: corey, 13-18 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column9: HAVE GONE UP AND DOWN ON DOSEAGE, BUT I THINK WE HAVE GOT IT RIGHT NOW.  I TAKE 3MG IN AM AND 4 MG IN PM.  ONLY SLIGHT NAUSEA AND SOME FINGER TINGLING AT TIMES.  OVERALL REAL HAPPY WITH THE DRUG.  NO REJECTION AND TAKE 5MG OF PREDISONE.

column2: 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have blood drawn every 2 months to check numerous blood chemistry (ie creatine, etc). This medication should not be taken without constant monitoring. column2: patty, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)

Those eased, but currently have short term memory loss, stomache problems, and mood swings.  Transplant drugs are difficult, but you MUST take them to save your transplanated organ!!!!

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Had a liver transplant last October and was started on a regiment of prograf right after transplant. I have been told by my Doctors that prograf and cellsep were instrumental in my successful transplant.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I was trying to find other kidney transplants who took prograf.  It has been okay so far, but don't know if prograf or myfortic is causing me stomach discomfort.  I always have trouble sleeping and often my bottom lip quivers.

column2: Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I was taking 2mg in morning and 1 at night.After a 1 1/2 year I started to reject.Increased to 3 morn and 2 at night. My #s came back down.My creatin went up and I have some tingling in the right hand.Hopefully DRs. will lower dosage when completely stabilized.

column2: alondra, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: other than loosing hair, I am very happy with prograf.  Works well and I don't have many side effecst from it.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: hair loosing

column2: jd, 75 or over Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: almost 11 years transplanted.  Take 2 mg prograf/day.

column2: pete, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Prograf for 4 years for a lung tx.  I had 2 mildly acute rejection bouts the first year which if fairly normal and I have had none the last three years.  Side effects for me include headaches about every three weeks which are nulified by hot tea/soda (caffine) and Tylenol.  I did have 3 days in a row of faintness after 2 years out.  We did every possible test and couldn't come up with a reason why.  With both side effects above it's hard to say if it's the Prograf, Imuran or something else. I haven't had any other side effects worth mentioning. Life is grand.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: i had alpha 1 as a kid- was transplanted march 21 1992. i am 17 years post surgery. i had an episode of rejection 2 years ago but have quickly recovered.  i take 2.5mg 2x per day :]

column2: flyboy, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: ON it for almost 6 years no problems except shakes once in a while

column2: diamondave, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am 3 months post transplant and have been on prograf from day1.Along with many other drugs.All in all they all work well to do their job but makes it hard to determine which drug causes which side effects.I have the shakey hands and achey muscles.Only occasional headaches tho.Thru my joining Transplant cafe.com,Ive learned that drinking much water helps considerably and is also necessary to prevent toxicity in the body.Prograf will ruin your kidneys if you dont drink a minimum of 64 ounces of water a day! If your on this drug,drink water!!It also helps to limit the side effects.

column2: godislove, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have only been taking prograf since April 09 and I have experienced many side effects.  Hair loss, tremors, agitation, infections, nerve pain, etc.  I noticed that I only got most of these side effects after my doctor raised my prograf amount.  I was taking 9 mg and I now take 7 mg, but I still am having these side effects.  My kidney was a high risk diceased kidney. Any suggestions from other patients out there.

column2: Roger, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was transplanted Nov 22 1999. After transplant I was taking 15 mg twice a day. Now after almost 10 years I take 2 mg twice a day. The first year was very rough for the side affects but after that everything has been going smooth

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Taking this drug since my kidney transplant Dec. 08 without any problems.  I'm monitoring moles and other skin issues.  I've also been monitoring my glucose levels which have been creeping up.  I need more exercise!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Eleven years post-transplant with no problems except need for small dosage blood pressure meds.  Use 3 mg 2X/day.  Very occasional tremors and no other discernable side effects.

column2: Blueyes, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Caregiver)
column9: My son has Nephrolic Syndrome. He has been on this medication for a year now and has been in full remission since 3 days after starting prograf.

column2: Crabbie7@aol.com, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: just tired of being sick & tired...

column1: Management of Body's Rejection to a Transplanted Kidney
column2: KateB, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Never told by any medical staff that a high side effect of Prograf is hair loss, to the point of full baldness. I've had elbow length hair all my life and within 5 1/2 months on this drug, have almost no hair left. Dr., seeing the extreme problem, has switched me to Neoral, which I hope is better. I do not want to lose the kidney, but I wish I knew of this side effect which leaves me in constant tears.

column2: EHS20, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I've been on prograf since i was 16, when i was first diagnosed with the auto-immune disorder. The dosage is now reduce from 10mg a day to now 3mg a day.When i was younger i suffered from tremors in my hands due to the mixture of meds i was on.I have suffered with pains and itch in legs and feet (pin and needle like pain). This still occures.Headaches are an everyday event and painkillers no longer work. Headaches increase with stress.Cant concentrate as good as i used to before the prograf.Hard to contain new information.Although there are many side effects the drung has now brought my liver count from 1300 to 17. The numbers have stayed steady over the past few years. It is a nessary evil.

column2: berly, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have used this med for 9 1/2 years...it's great.

column2: denijo, 7-12 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Caregiver)
column9: My daughter has been on Prograf for 8 years now, since her liver transplant as an infant.  On occasion she has headaches/migraines that sometimes result in vomiting.  Other than that, we've had no concerns with the drug.  Her lab results have been good and her growth and development seem to be at the same rate as a normal child her age.  Sometimes it can be difficult to determine whether or not something is from her condition or just that of an 8 year old.  Overall, pleased with the medication.

column2: Einman, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking 3 mg of prograff two times a day for 1 year and have only experienced slight hand tremors and gastrointestinal distress.  The GI distress in the form of slight nausea and diarrhea has been an increasing problem as time has passed.  Have appointment next month and will try to get dosage reduced.  The drug has been very effective in preventing rejection episodes.  I have had no additional side effects.

column2: Robert, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Caregiver)
column9: Prograf is toxic to kidneys - AvoidSubject: Kidney failure after long-term use of Prograf (following Liver Transplant).Patient's new kidney also began to slowly fail/decline (initially after transplant, while still on Prograf). The new kidney immediately began to recover after stopping the Prograf. Expert medical studies show that Prograf is toxic to the kidneys... Medical studies by experts at Albert Einstein Transplant Center support/promote the idea of stopping Prograf due to toxic effects on the kindey and using Cellcept (and Rapamune combo instead). Additional Comments: In my opinion, Prograf should be banned...as much better options are available (meds such as Cellcept and Rapamune that protect the kidney). By 2003, the studies and experts have known of the issues with Prograf. Yet nothing has been done in the interim to resolve the issues. Even today, Walter Reed transplant lists Prograf high on thier list of protocols, well above the Cellcept/Rapamune protocol. This is a travesty and needs to be corrected so that other patients do not continue to suffer from the use of the drug (Prograf) and the harmful effects on the kidney.

column2: Coachdiesel, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I take this medication because I had a bone marrow transplant from an unrelated donor. My Dr. gave this to me to prevent rejection. I take 2mg in the morning and 1 mg in the evening. So far the medication is working great. I haven't had any rejection symptoms. The only side effect I notice with this medication is that it makes my hands a little bit shaky. I had leukemia so if now all I have is shaky hands, I can deal with that. I'm just happy to be alive!

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
sok, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was started on this drug right after my transplant a little over 6 months ago, and it had to be stopped due to me going crazy. Apparently one of the side effects is posterior residual encephalitic syndrome. I was started on rapamune but experienced rejection 2-3 months out. prograf has been restarted and no more evidence of the PRES. It seems to be controlling the rejection though the 3 most serious side effects so far are the tremors and the peripheral swelling and cramps.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
pophorn54, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I`ve been taking it for 14 months,now I`m down to 4 mg 2x a day(when I remmenber only miss 1 or 2 night a week sometimes) have a appointment tommorrow going to ask if I could try to only take 1 pill a day hope it works out? Had only one week2 live so son gave part of his liver what a life saver! before transplant had pain in thighs still have don`t know what it from, know my feet hurt like there sowen but I live with it.

column2: docaye, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Like others I am having symptoms not described in literature.  Transplant done in 2005 for a genetic illness, so it is hard to separate which symptoms are due to that or the medication.  Down to 0.5mg twice a day because there is some nephrotoxicity.

column2: Neil, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
MeNtAlFoRMeTaL@aol.com, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Iv'e been taking prograf for the past 14 years because of my kidney tranplant. Knock on wood, Iv'e had no problems with this medication and no kidney rejection.

column2: yankeeflyer72, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Feb. 19th '09 will be 1 year since Liver Tx due to Cirrhosis caused by Hep-C. Also development of liver Cancer.  Initially I was taking 3.5mg twice daily, increased to 4mg daily, gradually reduced dosage until now I am at .5mg(1/2mg.) daily.  Blood work shows Prograf level at 6.4-6.9.  Type 2 Diabetes was controlled by diet prior to Tx.  Now must use insulin.  Very happy with results.  Also taking Ursodiol, Magnesium supplement, Mega-Vitamin supplent.

column2: SHARITA, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I CAN SAY LIKE MOST FOLKS THAT COMPARED TO MY LIFE BEFORE IM PLEASED. PROBLEMS NOTICED: MEMORY LOSS(NEED EXTRA TIME UNLIKE BEFORE). SKIN DISTUBANCES THAT WERE SEVERE IN THE BEGINING. HTN AND DIABETES AS WELL. I CONTROLLED THOSE TWO BY LOSSING WEIGHT AND CHANGING DIET WHICH HELPED.EXPERIENCED JOINT CARTILAGE DISTRUCTION WHICH LEAD TO ACL RECONSTUCTION,WHICH WAS VERY SUCCESFUL.IVE BEEN ON MEDS 3 YEARS NOW.

column2: Sonyia, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have a Mast Cell disease that almost cost me my life.  I broke out in hives so bad for over 7 years.  The last two I was taking over 7 epi shots a day, 100mg of predinsone, and 5 anti histimines, and I am a type I diabetic for over 13 years.  I went through several treatments of IVIG. (you can look that up on internet if you are interested in knowing how it is used.)  I quit responding with it, I was also on cyclosporen and after three months ended up in the hospital.  It quit working.  When I say sever hives I mean to the point I was taking epi shots just to breath.  Several times taken by ambulance and spending days at a time in the hospital on breathing treatments.  I was at the end of the line when one of my Doctors said lets try prograf and  if it does not work we will try Chemo. I also later had to be put on Gastrocrome.  Well 2 years later no epi shots, no hives and the only down side is my hair is thin and does not grow as well. Only shave about once every 3 months also. LOL. I do get sick alot, but it is better than dying or wanting to.  Blood pressure use to run 112 over 62 and now it is up to 142 over 84, but still not that bad.  Good luck to you all who have to use it.  I hope that my insurance will make sure I never loose this drug.

column2: bruter, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
rj, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: It has been nearly a year since my transplant. I am taking 4 mg am and pm. Night sweats is my biggest complaint and some sleepness nights. All and all has been very good for me and I am very pleased.

column2: My2Livers, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: the drug manufacturers don't tell us about hair loss, brain damage, severe depression, hallucinations, spinal cord damage, memory loss, cognitive problems, shaking, etc. I've been on it for 5 years and my pre-prograf MRI of my brain was fine. Now I have brain damage.I've also been diagnosed as severely bi-polar, and my once thick hair is all but gone!

column2: berdon, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: high creatinine level

column2: snicks, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Had a kidney transplant Dec. 23,2006 started on Prograf but had massive hairloss and was switched to cyclosporine. Hairloss was due to the surgery (massive trauma  to the body as told by my Dermotologist) swithced back to Prograf I've had no rejection issues but sideffects include sweating (not as bad as when first started, I use Secret Clinical, it helps) and thining hair on the crown of head. My dermo said to wait 18 mo. after surgery until the hair cycle gets back to normal then my hair stylest said to wait another 5 mo. to see new hair growth. That comes at the end of January 2009. But like another reviewer said if this is all I have to deal with, I think I'll be OK.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
nangal, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had kidney txp in 2000 and took cyclosporine - lots more side effects. Had pancreas txp 5/2008, some initial rejection issues and prograf level too high caused strange pains and inability to grip. Tremors starting to go away and bowels back on track (loose before) - now that dose lower. Newest issue is hair loss. Hoping that improves - or I'll get a wig! Happy so far, though it is a pricey med. No complaints after getting the gift of organ donation!

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Prograf has worked well for me for 8+ years. I developed high blood pressure and diabetes after transplant and due to the drug.  Some leg/joint pain which prevents significant exercise.  Overall, the side effects do not limit me from enjoying life. I have not experienced any episodes of rejection to date. Prograf is the only post transplant drug I've used, so can not compare to any others.

column2: johnnys33, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Prograf is a life saver, transplanted 1/2/2000 and doing great after 8+ years. Took heavy doses of steroids right after transplant but quickly moved to prograf. 3mg twice a day keeps the doctor away. I have diabetes just diagnosed this year, but I need to lose some weight (20 lbs.) and I'll be fine. Thanks to the transplant team and clinic follow-up at Univ of Penn.

column2: airmech3usa, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this medication due to a liver tx 5/2007 I am down to 2 mg twice a day. I take it with myfortic,ursodial, bactri and magnox, and so far I have had no rejection episodes or any side effects from any of these medications. I thank all of my liver transplant team for keeping me off steroids and going with the ones that I am taking now. It will be year 5/2008 since my transplant and I feel great. The first year is the hardest. I have not had any bad experiences so far and I hope that this will continue on.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years
column9: have taken this since heart transplant 4 years ago, no rejections, and feel great most of the time.

column2: scal0123, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: After 13 yrs, still going strong. Last year levels were higher than should be, developed high blood pressure & diabetes. Have a lot of foot & leg cramps, hard to maintain magnesium levels.

column2: choo, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: some loose stools on higher dosestill have some night sweatstremors on higher dose

column2: lucky chucky, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I'm satisfied because I haven't rejected (8 yrs and counting) but I did have absolutely the most horrifying nightmare the first time I used it (as I was warned to expect).  After that no nightmares, but I have not been able to sleep since (I'm not a wuss -  it's not because I fear another nightmare - that was a one time event -- but more because it happens to be one of the side effects.)  I take one half milligram of Xanax at night and sleep well and wake up easily and rested.  Bottom line.....it beats dying.

column2: ron0614, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Took this medicine 5 years caused multifocal leucoencephalophaty and now I am confined to a wheelchair.  Worked good while I took it, but side effects terrible.

column2: joe, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: much more effective than cellcept

column2: tara, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: After four years on this drug, I have had no rejection episodes. I have developed diabetes (but could be from prednisone). I take Reglan for nausea. My docs have been able to reduce my dose easily so my levels are relatively low.

column2: James, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
jaeri, 45-54 Female  (Patient)
column9: I'm not quite sure if the epiver which I use is the reason for my muscle spasms or the use of prograf.  I'm trying to dicipher this by educating myself about the uses of both.  I'm being treated for the effects of RLS as well, a previous condition but aggrivated further post possibly by other medications.  I'm trying to find out.  I'm not sure of the improvement due to all of the combined elements. It's been 6 months.  I'm just questioning what is the best way to treat my symptoms.  My doctors have changed from transplant to maintenance and I'm not sure that my doctor in maintenance is very interested in the maintenance just my stability.  I want to just feel better.  I'm giving my all and pay highly for it.  I'm finding self education to be my biggest tool.  Are the changes I'm experiencing from prograf, epiver or lack of magnesium.  My new liver  is a miracle all it's own.Post transplant and the monitoring of prograf at the center where I was treated was of the utmost quality.  We went through continuous blood monitoring and thorough physical monitoring for three months post.  Many in my group didn't pass after three months with prograf.  I basically AM VERY HAPPY.  Prograf seems the least intrusive therapy and maintenance in accordqance with my body and lifestyle.

column1: Body's Rejection of a Transplanted Organ
column2: tomasmortiz@aol.com, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: exelent for the treatment

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
Johnny, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I've used this drug for pancreas/kidney transplant in 2004.  I know about many of the side effects, and the one that I have had a problem with is interuption of sleep.  Taking Benedryl has helped with the sleep problem.  Overall, the drug is doing what it's supposed to do.  I've had no rejection episodes.

column2: VSTRAWBERRY, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I actually have had very few problems with Prograf in almost 8 years until a recent dip in my liver & prograft levels that resulted in a higher dose for a few weeks. I started severe headaches several weeks ago that will not go away and have constant nausea so bad I can hardly eat. I do have to take a sleeping pill at night because of insomnia I think is caused by the Prograf. All in all, I feel that I have done very well and have been lucky not to have had some of the bad side effects I have heard others talk about.

column2: oldgoat, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: The side effects can be bothersome, severe headaches lasting for days, rapid fatigue and hand tremors. However the alternative is more bothersome.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: This medication, in my opinion, is the best post kidney transplant medicine out here.  I havent rejected like I did while on Rapamune and hope I never do.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: the medication is okay, but it gave me alopecia.  was not listed as side effect.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I've suffered serious headaches as a result of this medication, in the form of tension headaches.  Unfortunately, muscle relaxers don't work for me (because of other auto-immune diseases), so sleeping them off is my only option.Also, major changes in the dose of this medication cause me to have flu-like symptoms for two to three days after the change.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Only 7 months out from lung Tx due to Cystic Fibrosis, I am hoping that this will continue to be effective!

column2: headsup670, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Overall good,but would like to know if prograf can cause,loss of cartliage in knees,arms.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Pain in the feet and the legs combine with the headaches has made this drug an evil necessity.

column2: KyBlueJay41, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I don't like the it because I am now a diabetic and have high blood pressure because of taking this medication, But it has kept me from rejecting my liver for 11 years now.
